title: Look things up with your camera using Visual Intelligence on iPhone 16
description: A new AI feature in iOS 18.2, Visual Intelligence gives iPhone 16 users a quick, easy way to find information on an object in the real world. (via Cult of Mac - Apple news, rumors, reviews and how-tos)
author: D. Griffin Jones
excerpt: A new AI feature in iOS 18.2, Visual Intelligence gives iPhone 16 users a quick, easy way to find information on an object in the real world.
text: How-To Search for products and get information with Visual Intelligence. Image: D. Griffin Jones/Cult of Mac The new Visual Intelligence feature provides a quick way to find information just by pointing the iPhone 16’s camera at an object in the real world. Then you can ask ChatGPT to explain what you’re looking at, do a reverse image search to find products and look things up visually, get information on a business as you walk down the street, and quickly add events to your calendar. New in iOS 18.3, you can also use it to identify plants… kind of. Here’s how it works. While Visual Intelligence relies heavily on third parties like ChatGPT and Google, its integration into the iPhone 16 makes it a powerful tool for everyday use. Apple’s new AI tool puts those incredibly useful information sources directly at your fingertips. However, you will need the right combo of hardware and software. Apple built Visual Intelligence exclusively for iPhone 16 owners, because the AI feature uses the new Camera Control button only available on those phones. And, as mentioned, you’ll need to be running iOS 18.2 or later. Table of contents: How to use Visual Intelligence on the iPhone 16 Install iOS 18.3 and enable Apple Intelligence Click and hold the Camera Control Look things up by snapping a picture Capture calendar events and look up businesses Identify plants How does Visual Intelligence work? More Apple Intelligence features Install iOS 18.3 and enable Apple Intelligence The first Apple Intelligence features became available in iOS 18.1. Visual Intelligence debuted in the second round of Apple’s AI features, in iOS 18.2, with additional capabilities in iOS 18.3. You can install the updates by going to Settings > General > Software Update. After you update to 18.3, you’ll be prompted during setup to enable Apple Intelligence. Click and hold the Camera Control You launch Visual Intelligence by clicking and holding the Camera Control, a gesture that mimics clicking and holding the side button to activate Siri. Because the Camera Control is only available on the iPhone 16, the feature is only available on those phones. Apple could likely enable a Control Center button to use the feature on iPhone 15 Pro models, but has not chosen to enable that. After clicking and holding the Camera Control, you’ll see an brief animation and an interface that looks similar to the iPhone camera, but with fewer controls. Look things up by snapping a picture Look up information on stuff around you with Visual Intelligence.Screenshot: D. Griffin Jones/Cult of Mac Click the Camera Control again, or tap one of the on-screen buttons, to look up whatever’s in view. The following two options are always available: Ask will send the picture to ChatGPT. OpenAI’s chatbot might be able to explain what you’re looking at, and you can ask it follow-up questions for more information. Trying this out with a bunch of weird objects around my office, I came away pretty impressed by what ChatGPT got right, but of course, I caught a few mistakes. You can’t entirely trust ChatGPT as your sole source of information; you should always fact-check for something important. Search uses a Google reverse-image search to identify the object. This proves useful if you want to find a product or object online. Tap on a result to open the link in Safari (or your preferred web browser). Capture calendar events and look up businesses Find the menu for a restaurant you’re passing by with a tap.Screenshot: D. Griffin Jones/Cult of Mac Visual Intelligence’s other smart features are more context-dependent: Events: You can point your iPhone 16 camera at something with event information on it, like a poster or document, and quickly add the event to your calendar. If it’s a music festival or concert, the tool might match it to an event and fill in details. It could become super-handy. Businesses: Take a picture of a restaurant, and Visual Intelligence will reference your location with Apple Maps information to look up the restaurant or business you’re looking at. You can see a phone number, website, menu and more. This seems like it could prove incredibly useful. If you’re walking down the street deciding where to eat, you might be able to quickly get information without manually searching for every name you see. Identify plants About half the time, Visual Intelligence shows the right plant out of three suggestions.Screenshot: D. Griffin Jones/Cult of Mac New in iOS 18.3, you can identify plants. Snap a picture of a plant, and you’ll get either one, two or three different suggestions based on its appearance. In my testing, this unfortunately isn’t too accurate, often suggesting the wrong plant. When it lists three different plants, it often has the correct one somewhere in the list — but unless it’s labeled, you can’t be sure which. Not to mention, if it’s labeled, you likely won’t need to use the feature in the first place. Tapping on a plant brings up information from Wikipedia. Tap again to open the full article with details. How does Visual Intelligence work? Technically speaking, none of these Visual Intelligence features are super-smart. ChatGPT and Google Reverse Image Search are both third-party services. Pulling information out of the iPhone camera like events and phone numbers is based on Live Text, a feature the iPhone has had for years. And Visual Intelligence does not use AI to do much when identifying businesses; it’s mostly using the iPhone’s GPS and compass with Apple Maps — any iPhone can do that. Even the new plant identification feature isn’t entirely new. Open Photos, search for “plant,” bring up a picture and swipe up — you’ll see a little info tag where you can look up the photographed plant. This feature works on all older devices running iOS 17. However, in practice, they’re still useful, practical features. It’s handy being able to access Live Text and visual look-up with a special interface, without the need to save a photo to your library. I think if Apple Intelligence wasn’t a big marketing and branding push, Apple would be more upfront about this being a convenient repackaging of different third-party services, rather than framing it as a new AI technology. More Apple Intelligence features How to use Apple Intelligence writing tools Remove an object from a photo with Apple Intelligence Hands-on with the first 10 Apple Intelligence features How to get Apple Intelligence features early — and in the EU We originally published this article on Visual Intelligence on December 10, 2024. We updated it with new information.
html:
• How-To

The new Visual Intelligence feature provides a quick way to find information just by pointing the iPhone 16’s camera at an object in the real world. Then you can ask ChatGPT to explain what you’re looking at, do a reverse image search to find products and look things up visually, get information on a business as you walk down the street, and quickly add events to your calendar.

New in iOS 18.3, you can also use it to identify plants… kind of. Here’s how it works.

While Visual Intelligence relies heavily on third parties like ChatGPT and Google, its integration into the iPhone 16 makes it a powerful tool for everyday use. Apple’s new AI tool puts those incredibly useful information sources directly at your fingertips.

However, you will need the right combo of hardware and software. Apple built Visual Intelligence exclusively for iPhone 16 owners, because the AI feature uses the new Camera Control button only available on those phones. And, as mentioned, you’ll need to be running iOS 18.2 or later.

Table of contents: How to use Visual Intelligence on the iPhone 16

  1. Install iOS 18.3 and enable Apple Intelligence
  2. Click and hold the Camera Control
  3. Look things up by snapping a picture
  4. Capture calendar events and look up businesses
  5. Identify plants
  6. How does Visual Intelligence work?
  7. More Apple Intelligence features

Install iOS 18.3 and enable Apple Intelligence

The first Apple Intelligence features became available in iOS 18.1. Visual Intelligence debuted in the second round of Apple’s AI features, in iOS 18.2, with additional capabilities in iOS 18.3. You can install the updates by going to Settings > General > Software Update.

After you update to 18.3, you’ll be prompted during setup to enable Apple Intelligence.

Click and hold the Camera Control

You launch Visual Intelligence by clicking and holding the Camera Control, a gesture that mimics clicking and holding the side button to activate Siri. Because the Camera Control is only available on the iPhone 16, the feature is only available on those phones. Apple could likely enable a Control Center button to use the feature on iPhone 15 Pro models, but has not chosen to enable that.

After clicking and holding the Camera Control, you’ll see an brief animation and an interface that looks similar to the iPhone camera, but with fewer controls.

Look things up by snapping a picture

Click the Camera Control again, or tap one of the on-screen buttons, to look up whatever’s in view. The following two options are always available:

  • Ask will send the picture to ChatGPT. OpenAI’s chatbot might be able to explain what you’re looking at, and you can ask it follow-up questions for more information. Trying this out with a bunch of weird objects around my office, I came away pretty impressed by what ChatGPT got right, but of course, I caught a few mistakes. You can’t entirely trust ChatGPT as your sole source of information; you should always fact-check for something important.
  • Search uses a Google reverse-image search to identify the object. This proves useful if you want to find a product or object online. Tap on a result to open the link in Safari (or your preferred web browser).

Capture calendar events and look up businesses

Visual Intelligence’s other smart features are more context-dependent:

  • Events: You can point your iPhone 16 camera at something with event information on it, like a poster or document, and quickly add the event to your calendar. If it’s a music festival or concert, the tool might match it to an event and fill in details. It could become super-handy.
  • Businesses: Take a picture of a restaurant, and Visual Intelligence will reference your location with Apple Maps information to look up the restaurant or business you’re looking at. You can see a phone number, website, menu and more. This seems like it could prove incredibly useful. If you’re walking down the street deciding where to eat, you might be able to quickly get information without manually searching for every name you see.

Identify plants

New in iOS 18.3, you can identify plants. Snap a picture of a plant, and you’ll get either one, two or three different suggestions based on its appearance.

In my testing, this unfortunately isn’t too accurate, often suggesting the wrong plant. When it lists three different plants, it often has the correct one somewhere in the list — but unless it’s labeled, you can’t be sure which. Not to mention, if it’s labeled, you likely won’t need to use the feature in the first place.

Tapping on a plant brings up information from Wikipedia. Tap again to open the full article with details.

How does Visual Intelligence work?

Technically speaking, none of these Visual Intelligence features are super-smart. ChatGPT and Google Reverse Image Search are both third-party services. Pulling information out of the iPhone camera like events and phone numbers is based on Live Text, a feature the iPhone has had for years. And Visual Intelligence does not use AI to do much when identifying businesses; it’s mostly using the iPhone’s GPS and compass with Apple Maps — any iPhone can do that.

Even the new plant identification feature isn’t entirely new. Open Photos, search for “plant,” bring up a picture and swipe up — you’ll see a little info tag where you can look up the photographed plant. This feature works on all older devices running iOS 17.

However, in practice, they’re still useful, practical features. It’s handy being able to access Live Text and visual look-up with a special interface, without the need to save a photo to your library. I think if Apple Intelligence wasn’t a big marketing and branding push, Apple would be more upfront about this being a convenient repackaging of different third-party services, rather than framing it as a new AI technology.

More Apple Intelligence features

  • How to use Apple Intelligence writing tools
  • Remove an object from a photo with Apple Intelligence
  • Hands-on with the first 10 Apple Intelligence features
  • How to get Apple Intelligence features early — and in the EU

We originally published this article on Visual Intelligence on December 10, 2024. We updated it with new information.
